metaDescription: Calculate overtime pay in Ireland including tax deductions. PAYE, USC, PRSI on extra hours. Free 2026 rates calculator.
intro: Calculate your overtime pay in Ireland with our comprehensive tax calculator. Understanding how overtime is taxed is crucial for maximizing your take-home earnings from extra hours worked. Irish law typically requires overtime to be paid at time-and-a-half (1.5x) or double time (2x) your normal hourly rate, but these payments are taxed at your marginal rate, potentially pushing you into higher tax brackets. This calculator uses official 2026 Revenue.ie rates to show you exactly how much tax you'll pay on overtime earnings, including PAYE income tax, Universal Social Charge (USC), and Pay Related Social Insurance (PRSI) contributions. Whether you work occasional overtime or regularly put in extra hours, this tool helps you understand the true value of your overtime work.
howThisCalculatorWorks: This Ireland overtime pay calculator determines your take-home overtime earnings by first calculating the gross overtime pay (base salary ÷ 52 weeks ÷ contracted hours × overtime hours × overtime multiplier), then applying Irish tax rates. Overtime is taxed at your marginal PAYE rate - if your regular salary puts you in the 20% bracket but overtime pushes you into the 40% bracket, the overtime is taxed at 40%. USC and PRSI are calculated on total earnings. The calculator shows both the overtime pay breakdown and your total salary including overtime, so you can see the overall tax impact. Irish employment law generally requires overtime rates of 1.5x for weekdays and 2x for weekends/holidays, though individual contracts may vary.

overtimeRules.title: Irish Overtime Pay Rules
rules: **Legal Requirement:** Most Irish employment contracts require overtime pay at premium rates
**Standard Rates:** Time-and-a-half (1.5x) for normal overtime, double time (2x) for Sundays/holidays
**Contract Variations:** Some contracts specify different rates or overtime banking arrangements
**Tax Treatment:** Overtime is taxed at marginal rates, potentially in higher tax brackets
**PRSI Impact:** Overtime increases total earnings, affecting social insurance contributions
**USC Impact:** Higher total income may push overtime into higher USC brackets

faqs.question: How is overtime taxed in Ireland?
faqs.answer: Overtime pay is taxed at your marginal PAYE rate. If your regular salary keeps you in the 20% bracket but overtime pushes you into the 40% bracket, the overtime is taxed at 40%. USC and PRSI are calculated on your total earnings.

faqs.question: What's the standard overtime rate in Ireland?
faqs.answer: Irish law generally requires time-and-a-half (1.5x your normal rate) for overtime worked on weekdays, and double time (2x) for overtime worked on Sundays or public holidays.

faqs.question: Does overtime affect my tax bracket?
faqs.answer: Yes, overtime increases your total annual earnings, potentially pushing you into higher PAYE tax brackets and USC bands. The overtime itself is taxed at your new marginal rate.

faqs.question: Can I bank overtime instead of getting paid immediately?
faqs.answer: Some Irish employers offer overtime banking schemes where you can accumulate overtime hours for future time off. Check your employment contract for specific arrangements.

faqs.question: How do I calculate my overtime rate?
faqs.answer: Divide your annual salary by 52 weeks, then divide by your contracted weekly hours. Multiply by the overtime multiplier (usually 1.5 or 2.0) for your overtime rate.
